<English>: Increase the crew level to {reqLevel} ({currentLevelText}) in order to be able to complete the qualification upgrade course to level {wantedQualify} ({trainCost}).
The {wantedQualify} qualification gives the bonus of {bonusValue} to all crew skills for this vehicle.

Protected ammunition compartment.
If the bulkhead of this compartment is not penetrated when the armor is breached,
it provides full protection against propellant fires.
If the ammunition load includes explosive-filled projectiles (HE, HEAT, HESH),
it may provide protection in the event of detonation of a small number of such rounds.

External or protected fuel tanks.
These tanks are located outside the vehicle’s under-armor volume,
or are protected by separate armor elements.
If they are hit and catch fire, the fire does not damage the tank’s internal modules
or the crew and burns out on its own after some time.
Auxiliary power unit. Supplies power to the vehicle when the main engine is shut down
Slip ring. Transfers power from the hull to the turret
If it fails, these systems cannot be used:

Their numbers is updated daily at <color=@activeTextColor>{time}</color>.
All daily universal backups are used up. Please select another universal backup or another vehicle to spawn.
This vehicle is given to you for the current mission and you can use it equally with your own.

Armor steel with high hardness and strength
Combined armor with high hardness and strength
Armor aluminum with high hardness and strength
Without armor and without high hardness and strength

Aramid fabric or ultra-high-molecular-weight polyethylene panels installed in the crew compartments of armored vehicles reduce the angle and velocity of fragments, significantly improving crew and equipment protection from small fragments generated during armor penetration.

Panels made of polyethylene and polyisobutylene are installed inside and outside the tank. Their primary purpose is to reduce the impact on the crew during a nuclear explosion, but in some cases they can also protect the crew and equipment from small fragments generated during armor penetration by reducing their velocity and angle of flight, although this is less effective than a specialized spall liner.

Armor protection is made using composite armor, which can consist of multiple layers of dissimilar materials, such as textolite, ceramic elements, NERA layers, and other armor materials. This approach provides a lighter weight than standard steel armor while maintaining the same resistance. For main battle tanks, composite armor is typically used in the most heavily protected frontal areas of the hull and turret.

Armor protection is manufactured partially or entirely using aluminum alloys. Aluminum armor provides a reduction in armor weight compared to homogeneous steel armor of the same resistance. The armor resistance of aluminum depends on the manufacturing technology and alloying elements used in its production.

Armor protection is made using steel armor plates. The projectile resistance of armor steel depends on the manufacturing technology. Rolled armor has higher armor resistance than cast armor due to the uniform distribution of defects during the rolling process. Certain types of steel, such as electroslag remelted steel and high-hardness steel, offer greater resistance than conventional steel armor.
There is no armor protection, the vehicle is made of non-armored materials and is not designed to be under enemy fire.
Bulletproof armor is designed to protect a combat vehicle from small arms fire and shell fragments.

Projectile-proof armor is designed to protect a combat vehicle from tank and anti-tank gunfire. For medium and main battle tanks, this typically means providing projectile-proof protection from the front, while the sides and rear are often significantly less protected.

Projectile-proof armor is designed to protect a combat vehicle from tank and anti-tank gunfire. For heavy tanks, this typically means the ability to withstand fire from more powerful guns than medium tanks, or over a wider range of frontal arc.
Projectile-proof armor is designed to protect a combat vehicle from tank and anti-tank gunfire.
Spall armor is designed to protect a combat vehicle from shell and rocket fragments in the event of an indirect hit.
Turn time is how quickly your plane will make a 360° turn under ideal conditions, which you won't encounter in a real game

Rate of climb is a performance characteristic of an aircraft that determines its maneuverability in the vertical plane; it is expressed in the speed capabilities of the aircraft as it gains altitude in flight and is measured in meters per second
Maximum altitude is the highest altitude at which steady level flight at a constant speed is possible with maximum thrust or engine power
Maximum speed is the maximum speed an aircraft can reach
The wing loading determines the takeoff and landing speed of an aircraft, its maneuverability, maximum flight distance and other characteristics
Automatic target tracking is a system that automatically tracks the movement of a target after it has been detected and captured, calculating its current coordinates and movement parameters
You need to purchase this item in the modification menu first.

For "High" graphics quality settings, the anti-aliasing method has been changed to "TSR", which gives a significant increase in image quality but with some decline in performance. You can always change the anti-aliasing method by going to the graphic settings.
